title: Down syndrome: Single woman uses IVF to become mum to baby with disability
text:
"Everyone I told was in shock. I had no idea if I could do this."

An explanation of IVF, how it works and the chances of falling pregnant for older women.

IVF: What are your chances for success? 00:20:46

Michele stared at her best friend in complete disbelief as tears began to stream down her face.

The then-40-year-old American woman couldn’t believe what she was hearing.

It seemed crazy that in all the years of dreaming of a husband and a family - she had never considered this.

Instantly, she knew it was the right thing to do.

“Her words resonated with the deepest part of my heart," Michele first wrote on Love What Matters.

"You can be a mum. You don’t need a husband. And you won’t be alone," her best friend said.

“It surfaced something so deep in me - all I could do was respond with tears," Michele vividly recalled.

Michele decided she was going to have a baby on her own. Source: Michele Elizaga

"Questions and fears swirling in my head”

The next morning, Michele woke up with a sense of purpose.

She had decided that she was going to have a baby on her own, "in spite of the questions and fears swirling in my head”.

Michele had no idea if she could financially support a baby, no plan for what would happen if she met someone - or how her family would react.

But she found that none of that mattered - she knew she had made the right decision.

This sense of certainty stayed with Michele throughout the entire IVF process.

When her fertility doctor suggested she purchase multiple vials of sperm – Michele somehow knew that she would only need one.

Surprisingly, Michele fell pregnant on the first try. Source: Michele Elizaga

It was meant to be

Although the chance of her conceiving at 40 was extremely low, she just knew that she would be having a baby.

In the end, she chose a donor who seemed similar to her – and had chosen to become a sperm donor to help others struggling to start a family.

A short time later, Michele was told that she was ovulating and went in for her IUI stat.

Doctors gave her an at-home pregnancy test to take in a couple of weeks, but warned her that IVF often isn’t successful the first time.

But Michele proved them wrong, with the test coming back positive within a matter of days.

Michele's family couldn't believe she was doing this by herself. Source: Michele Elizaga

"I’m still single, and I haven’t had sex"

In complete shock, Michele now had to work out how to tell everyone in her life that she was having a baby alone.

The first people she called were her parents, who live in the Philippines.

“So first, I need you to know I’m still single, and I haven’t had sex with anyone…but I’m pregnant,” Michele remembered telling her parents.

“After they got over the shock, they were happy for me.

“And from there, I told my sisters and then my best friends and made so many phone calls and shared the news with so many in the weeks that followed.”

Michele's best friend was by her side as she went into labour. Source: Michele Elizaga

“He’s a fighter"

As Michele’s pregnancy progressed, she felt certain that she was having a girl.

So she got the shock of her life when she found out she was actually having a boy.

But that wasn’t the only surprise – Michele found out that her baby had Down syndrome.

Although the news came as a shock, it never crossed Michele's mind for a second to consider terminating the pregnancy.

“Most babies with a chromosomal abnormality like Down syndrome don’t make it to 12 weeks, and my baby did,” she said.

“He’s a fighter.”

Little Matthew arrived and went straight into NICU. Source: Michele Elizaga

“While it wasn’t what I had hoped - it was the sweetest reunion"

Michele’s baby continued to fight after he was born via emergency C-section.

Throughout labour, the baby’s heart had plummeted each time Michele tried to push.

There was a point when Michele remembers turning to her best friend and asking if she was about to lose the baby.

But little Matthew didn’t give up.

After he arrived, doctors rushed him straight into the NICU to put him on oxygen.

“It wasn’t until nearly five hours after his birth we would meet in the NICU while I was still nauseous and still feeling some of the negative effects of the anesthesia,” Michele said.

“While it wasn’t what I had hoped, it was the sweetest reunion and there was nothing like holding this little baby that grew inside of me.”

Matthew spent time in the NICU learning to breathe on his own. Source: Michele Elizaga

"Single parenting is not for the faint of heart"

Matthew is now four-and-a-half months old, and has now been at home longer than he was in the NICU.

Although Michele said she has never been more “physically, mentally and emotionally exhausted,” she’s also “never felt more empowered and whole”.

“The whole time, I thought I chose Matthew, but knowing he chose me has been the greatest source of my strength,” she added.

“Matthew has pulled strength out of me I never knew I had and made me love like I never knew I could. The joy he continually brings to my heart feels like a dream.

“I’m still new to all of this but suffice to say, single parenting is not for the faint of heart. Nor is having a child with special needs.

"But Matthew choosing me has been the greatest gift I have ever received.”

Follow Michele on Instagram.

Matthew is now four and a half months old. Source: Michele Elizaga
